context: The fourth Yuan emperor, <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>Buyantu Khan<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> (Ayurbarwada), was a competent emperor. He was the first Yuan emperor to <a1_0><a1_1><b6_0>actively support and <a1_2>adopt mainstream Chinese culture<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> after the reign of Kublai, to the discontent of some Mongol elite. He had been mentored by <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><b7_0>Li Meng<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>, a Confucian academic. He made many reforms, including the liquidation of <a3_0><a3_2>the <a3_1><b8_0>Department of State Affairs<b8_0/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> (Chinese: 尚書省), which resulted in the execution of five of the highest-ranking officials. Starting in <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><b9_0>1313<b9_0/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> the traditional imperial examinations were reintroduced for prospective officials, testing their knowledge on significant historical works. Also, he codified much of the law, as well as publishing or translating a number of Chinese books and works.
